title: They say 'high skill cap champs should have lower win rates'.

replies.body:
he has to get a kill though XD
{{champion:119}} :  R!!!!  there's your kill!

*misses*

{{champion:119}} Draaaven...

dont forget, it will come back

*missed again*

{{champion:119}}  DRAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAVEN!!!

And his team secures 3 Infernals, Elder and Baron.

Gotta love them 600+ AD crits.
play jhin if you want that every game den
Draven can hit you 5 times by the time you finish reloading LOL
I'd like to see him live to me reloading.
but jhin cant do 600+ ad crits with at least 2 atk speed

Where is the skill in Draven? Is it managing your spinning axes? Because after you learn how to do that he can't be that hard considering his stupid damage in the early game

Edit: lol, salty Draven mains much? I know Sion doesn't require much skill to execute, as least I can admit that
Draven is a high skill cap champion, especially compared to all other adcs.

http://www.leagueofgraphs.com/champions/stats/draven/adc/platinum

http://www.leagueofgraphs.com/champions/stats/tristana/adc/platinum

http://www.leagueofgraphs.com/champions/stats/varus/adc/platinum
http://www.leagueofgraphs.com/champions/stats/missfortune/adc/platinum

Not really. Statistics wise, all marksmen are the same curve just a few examples above. Some are stronger some are weaker but have same curve/ close winrate.
Try playing him. You'll figure it out

Only difficult thing about him is figuring out when to let go of axes and when to catch them. To learn that takes around 5 games to 100 depending on how fast at learning/ good the player playing draven is.  Otherwise his skillcap is average as any other immobile marksmen in the game. 


Draven's kit's own skill can be shown 
 Canceling dashes with e
 Using w to dodge things properly
Deciding to catch or drop axes
 Hitting skill shots in kit/animation canceling
Kog'maw's skill example
Proper usage of w/ making sure not to waste w
 Hitting skillshots in kit
 Hitting skill shots in kit/animation canceling
Learning when to use spells like q and e 

But point is that draven himself is an average skillcap honestly. High skill floor definitely but thats the main difference in difficulty compared to other marksmen.

> Only difficult thing about him is figuring out when to let go of axes and when to catch them. 

Lol no its not.

You are constantly microing two axes. You have to anticipate the flow of the fight and manually position them correctly in advance. Failure to do so means you lose a large chunk of your DPS.

Kog, in comparison is extremely easy mechanically. Kog's spells account for a very small amount of his damage in an actual team fight. The biggest thing you need to do as Kog is position correctly. This is an example of game knowledge, not mechanics. This applies to all immobile damage sources. The only real mechanically difficult part of Kog is orb walking properly which is no different from any ADC.

To be fair draven also has more tools to repostion with his e and w movement speed buff that also resets on catching axes. meaning overall positioning  is harder on kog'maw that and draven is normally goes a way tankier build then normal. Making his postioning even less punshing to get hit by, but sure he loses a decent amount of dps if he can't catch a single axe, but even 3 axes is 150+3.05 bonus ad in damage along with  40% as isn't that punishing. 

That and his base offensive stats are really good for a marksmen
http://leagueoflegends.wikia.com/wiki/Draven
0.679 base attack speed with 2.7% scaling(Base is  really above average)
55 base ad with 2.91 ad per level scaling(Good ad scaling then most marksmen)

But I do agree that his main thing that gives him his skillcap is his axes, but it is about above average in terms of difficulty of marksmen.  (I consider kalista having highest skillcap followed by xayah then ezreal, then utility marksmen then draven is equal to vayne in terms of skillcap)

Axes literaly go where you want them to. Its not that hard
There are some mechanics you should know like ER Flashing and carrying animation triple axe magement etc 

As for kog maw skillcap

You need some damn fast fingers or scripts to unlock him

Pre revert video though https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QzW1oET3n-8

> [{quoted}](name=Sub HeroCro,realm=EUNE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=i1Y20xOk,comment-id=0001000100000000000000000002,timestamp=2017-05-24T08:55:01.300+0000)
>

> 
> Pre revert video though 


You literally just lost all credibility when you linked a pre revert video. It shows you have zero comprehension of what orb walking really means. You COULDN'T have orbwalked with kog pre revert, his attack speed was too high unless you used scripts.


Draven is the hardest adc, period. OP's argument also failed to account for sample sizes. A higher skill cap champion has its winrate depressed overall, but not for dedicated mains.

https://i.gyazo.com/015b5c1bf57ab8a1c89d5c363b3e3972.png

Which as you can see, he did not account for at all.
you may be able to defend he could be high skill cap, but srsly, not the hardest

Draven's skill cap (that sets him above a "standard" adc) are

1. Microing
2. Decision Making

Microing because of how Axes work. Two is hard enough, some Dravens can juggle 3 (with sufficient attackspeed)

Draven's decision making is more polar than other ADCs; it's more high risk and reward. If you can't make decisions and commit to them, playing Draven is a bad idea.
and then you get fabbby who will juggle 4-5 axes in a team fight...
4-5 axes don't really add that much to your DPS. 3 is the most efficient at maximising your dps.

> [{quoted}](name=ShadowParker,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=i1Y20xOk,comment-id=00010001,timestamp=2017-05-23T22:22:19.764+0000)
>
> Draven is a high skill cap champion, especially compared to all other adcs.

I wouldn't go as far as saying "all other adc's." Vayne, Lucian, and Ezreal are all tough in their own right (to play them effectively, at least â€” especially Vayne).

But yes, Draven is a hard adc to play.
I wouldn't call Lucian tough to play. He's bogstandard.
Yeah, his spinning axes create a skill floor, which i think is the confusion. Once you learn to direct where your axes will fall you've basically mastered him.

"Why, thank you."
Did not know you can direct, til now :D (don't own him)
I don't even play Draven, but I do know if you move after throwing an axe before it hits the target, it will go in the same direction you moved too.

Muhahahah people are starting to realize my main is op

oh wait

oh no

please no

Coming from a draven main.
this is because they're nerfing pretty much everything that stops him, and buffing what gives him power
{{item:3812}} helped
CRIT: helped him
{{champion:51}} nerfs are going to help him
lot of assassin nerfs and survivability buffs helped him

They've also given him direct buffs a couple times already.

I'm actually scared every time Draven gets mentioned in patch notes, because it's always another small buff that pushes him even further over the top.

The play rate doesnt tell the whole story. 
If we look at http://champion.gg/champion/Draven/ADC?league=
He doesn't have a positive winrate until 50+ games. Riven doesn't until 101+
If we look at ahri or annie, they have positive winrates at 1-51 games. 
Not the whole reason just a thought

Champion.gg's whole player experience thing has been broken for months and everyone knows it. 

For example, it says 75% of his games are played by the "under 50 games" demographic at 45% win rate, yet his overall win rate is 53%?

Not to mention there are some champs where the graphs and the stats they give are actually mathematically impossible to be correct when compared
Please use a more reliable source.
What's wrong with champion.gg?

From what I understand, champion.gg only pulls data from the first few days of each patch, while players are still getting used to changes, leading to wildly inaccurate data. I've heard that league of graphs is far more reliable.
I'm a personal fan of Lolalytics.

It's because of GA. Before if you put the resources into killing a fed Draven he would lose his stacks and you had a window to catch up. Now he just builds GA second and keeps his stacks even if he fucks up

I'd say {{champion:119}} and {{champion:202}} are probably the most difficult ADCs. {{champion:119}} requires faster reflexes and coordination than most adcs, and Playing {{champion:202}} requires much more planning and precision than other adcs.

Of course, this is just my opinion.
I love Jhin so much, his skill cap isn't all twitch bullshit button mashing. It takes actual talent to be good with Jhin, who has almost no mobility or self-peel.
"no self peel" can outrun an udyr...and has a snare?
If you are out running an udyr as Jhin than Udyr has got issues..
https://youtu.be/BrP0H-n0x3Q
"The build only works this effectively in URF mode"
Also requires a lot of forethought, which I respect.

Yeah, speaking of high skill cap champs. Garen has 47% in Plat+, so that's kinda fair.

######landing these ults is really hard man

"High skillcap champs are supposed to have lower winrates"
"Simple champs are supposed to have lower winrates"

Then what is supposed to have a high winrate?
{{champion:64}}
personally i think that high skill caps SHOULDNT have lower winrates as long as games played is in line.

Honestly Draven isn't TOO terribly hard to play considering that mid game three autos can kill someone.

If a Draven gets out of control then it's the supports fault (especially if they  are an engage or poke support). The support needs to make sure that Draven is paying for every axe he catches or even better zone him from catching them
"its the supports fault" cringe
